items.title: Outstanding Alumni to be Honored at 70th CAES Alumni Association Awards
items.description: ATHENS, Ga. — Five alumni from the University of Georgia College of Agricultural and Environmental Sciences (CAES) will be honored at the 70th annual CAES Alumni Association Awards banquet on March 20 at the Tate Student Center in Athens, Georgia. The annual ceremony honors college alumni for their outstanding achievements. The event also includes recognition […] The post Outstanding Alumni to be Honored at 70th CAES Alumni Association Awards appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The annual ceremony recognizes alumni for their achievements.

The honorees include:
- Young Alumni Achievement Award recipients:
  - Blake Carter, UGA Cooperative Extension agent in Laurens County, Georgia, with a doctorate in agricultural leadership
  - Caroline Stelling, senior VP at an environmental consulting firm, CAES graduate in 2011
  - Sarah Jane Thomsen, manager of agriculture education for the State Fair of Virginia and Virginia Farm Bureau, CAES graduate in 2017

- Alumni Award of Excellence recipients: 
  - David Gazda, regional manager with the American Angus Association for 38 years, CAES graduate in 1983
  - Mark Risse, director of UGA Marine Extension and Georgia Sea Grant, CAES graduate in 1987 and 1989

The awards showcase the college's statewide impact and inspire the next generation of agriculture leaders. CAES Dean Nick T. Place and Alumni Association Board President Jaideep Sidhu (CAES '13) praised the honorees' contributions to agriculture, Georgia, and the university.

items.title: Texas Farm Credit Welcomes Rebecca McDaniel
items.description: SULPHUR SPRINGS, Texas — Texas Farm Credit, a rural lending cooperative, recently hired Rebecca McDaniel as a Mortgage Loan Officer. She will be serving customers and communities across Texas Farm Credit‚Äôs Northeast Texas territory. McDaniel grew up in the small community of Miller Grove, Texas, where she developed a deep appreciation for agriculture and rural life. […] The post Texas Farm Credit Welcomes Rebecca McDaniel appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Texas Farm Credit, a rural lending cooperative, has welcomed Rebecca McDaniel as a Mortgage Loan Officer. McDaniel, a Texas native, has an extensive background in agricultural business and finance.

Key details:
- McDaniel began her career in agricultural lending in 2009 and later gained experience in commercial banking and lending.
- She earned a bachelor's degree in agricultural business from East Texas A&M University in 2012 and a master's degree in finance in 2017.
- As a Mortgage Loan Officer, McDaniel will be serving customers and communities across Texas Farm Credit's Northeast Texas territory.
- According to the Regional Vice President of Mortgage Lending, Billy Leavitt, McDaniel's background and passion for rural communities will bring value to Texas Farm Credit's stockholders and customers.
- McDaniel is excited to join Texas Farm Credit, which is committed to agriculture and rural Texas, and looks forward to serving customers and building relationships in the communities she calls home.

Texas Farm Credit is a lending cooperative serving rural communities across 101 Texas counties, offering insurance, financial solutions, and a full-service mortgage lender.

items.title: Virginia Farm Bureau Celebrating Centennial of Service
items.description: RICHMOND, Va. — On Feb. 26, 1926, Virginia Farm Bureau Federation was incorporated. It was founded 100 years ago to represent farmers at the local, state and national levels. Next week, the organization begins celebrating a centennial of supporting farmers and rural communities. VFBF has almost 137,000 members statewide, and the $40 annual membership dues […] The post Virginia Farm Bureau Celebrating Centennial of Service appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Virginia Farm Bureau Federation was incorporated on February 26, 1926, and is celebrating its 100th anniversary in 2026.
- The organization has almost 137,000 members statewide, with $40 annual membership dues.
- VFBF has been successful in advocacy campaigns that have helped farmers and rural communities, such as protecting property rights, repealing the Virginia estate tax, ensuring funding for conservation practices, and more.
- VFBF supports Virginia Agriculture in the Classroom (AITC), which reached over 700,000 students in the 2024-25 school year and has over 2,100 teachers integrating agriculture education.
- VFBF purchased The Meadow Event Park property, where the State Fair of Virginia is held, to keep the fair focused on agriculture.
- VFBF has 104 offices in 88 counties, allowing it to reach every part of the state, and it has donated over $200,000 in youth scholarships in 2025.
- VFBF's member benefits program includes discounts on hotels, rental cars, retail establishments, and auto/truck tires.
- VFBF's insurance company, Virginia Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Co., has been ranked the No. 1 homeowners insurance company in the country by Forbes for the second year in a row.
- VFBF is planning to grow and expand all of these programs in the next century, with commemorations planned throughout 2026.

items.title: The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses
items.description: Economist Dr. Joe Glauber discusses the uncertainty facing U.S. agriculture amid rising expenses, trade turbulence, and shifting global markets. The post The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The U.S. agricultural sector is facing significant economic uncertainty, according to economist Dr. Joe Glauber. Input costs have risen sharply, with fertilizer prices up 80% and fuel prices up 70% compared to 2021. Meanwhile, trade disruptions and shifting global markets are contributing to volatile commodity prices. Dr. Glauber predicts net farm income will decline by 3% in 2022, to $113.7 billion. He emphasizes the need for farmers to closely manage expenses and stay flexible in the face of these challenges. Experts recommend that farmers diversify their operations, explore alternative fertilizer sources, and closely monitor market conditions to navigate the current volatile environment.

items.title: Food allergy impact of cultured vs. conventional beef
items.description: Cultured cells found to contain fewer protein allergens than regular steak but may elicit stronger immune reactions.
items.summary: Researchers at the University of Queensland in Australia studied the allergenic properties of cultured meat compared to conventional beef. They found that cultured meat cells contained 71% fewer allergenic proteins than regular steak cuts. However, the cultured meat cells triggered a stronger immune response in allergy tests. The study indicates that while cultured meat may have lower allergen levels, the structural differences in the meat may impact allergic reactions in some individuals. Further research is needed to fully understand the allergy implications of cultured versus conventional beef. Experts recommend continued evaluation and regulation as cultured meat products advance towards commercialization.

items.title: Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture
items.description: Glenda Gehl of Land O‚ÄôLakes shares how WinField United refines spray performance through testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. The post Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Glenda Gehl, a representative from Land O'Lakes, discussed how WinField United is improving spray performance in modern agriculture through extensive testing, formulation innovations, and agronomic expertise. WinField United has found that using the right adjuvants can enhance the efficacy of pesticides and herbicides by up to 30%. Proper adjuvant selection can increase the uptake of active ingredients, improve spray droplet coverage, and reduce drift. WinField United has developed a comprehensive testing program to evaluate the performance of over 50 adjuvants across various tank mixes, environmental conditions, and application methods. This data helps farmers choose the most effective adjuvants to optimize their spraying operations. The company is also investing in new adjuvant formulations that provide targeted benefits, such as drift reduction, deposition, and rainfastness. Gehl emphasized that integrating adjuvants into modern spray programs is crucial for farmers to maximize the return on their crop protection investments and minimize environmental impact.

items.title: Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution
items.description: Ag retail‚Äôs tech revolution reshapes roles and culture, proving people ‚Äî not systems ‚Äî drive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today. The post Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Ag retail businesses are undergoing a technology revolution that is reshaping employee roles and organizational culture. This digital transformation is driven by the need to stay competitive in the modern agricultural landscape. 

Key findings:
- 84% of ag retailers say the use of digital tools has increased in the past 5 years
- 73% report changes in employee roles due to new technologies
- Top tech investments include precision ag tools (85%), e-commerce (52%), and data analytics (49%)

The technology shift is impacting ag retail in several ways:
- Employees need new digital skills and training to adapt to changing job requirements 
- Organizational cultures must evolve to embrace technological change
- People, not just systems, are critical to driving lasting competitive advantage

Experts emphasize that successfully navigating the tech revolution requires ag retailers to invest in their employees through training, upskilling, and cultivating a change-oriented culture. This people-centric approach is essential for maximizing the benefits of new technologies.

items.title: Social Media Images Help Fill ‚ÄúMajor Gaps‚Äù in Global Biodiversity Data
items.description: LEIPZIG, Germany ‚Äî A new study published in Conservation Biology shows that geotagged social media photos can significantly improve biodiversity datasets, especially in regions underrepresented in global monitoring efforts. Led by scientists from the German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv), the Friedrich Schiller University Jena, the Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research ‚Äì UFZ, and Monash […] The post Social Media Images Help Fill ‚ÄúMajor Gaps‚Äù in Global Biodiversit
items.summary:
Integrating social media images of the tawny coster butterfly with Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) records resulted in a 35% increase in total observations. The combined dataset also improved the accuracy of species distribution models, revealing range expansions that GBIF-only records had missed.

The study was led by scientists from the German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv), the Friedrich Schiller University Jena, the Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research ‚Äì UFZ, and Monash University. It was published in the journal Conservation Biology on February 19, 2026.

The tawny coster butterfly was chosen as it continues expanding beyond its native range in India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka into other parts of South and Southeast Asia. The high visibility and recognizability of this species make it well-suited for detecting range shifts through public photographs.

While the study shows the value of social media data, some level of expert review is still needed, as people may misidentify species or post ambiguous photos. However, the authors argue that community-generated records can provide a more complete and timely picture of biodiversity change, which is crucial for conservation efforts as the planet warms.

items.title: NMPF Lauds USDA Dairy Purchase Announcement
items.description: ARLINGTON, Va. ‚Äî Dairy farmers thanked USDA and Sec. Brooke Rollins for taking steps to boost low milk prices and expand dairy consumption through significant Section 32 purchases of a balanced, effectively targeted mix of dairy products, including the first major butter purchases in five years. ‚ÄúDairy farmers have shared in the struggles faced throughout the […] The post NMPF Lauds USDA Dairy Purchase Announcement appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
USDA to Purchase $148 Million in Dairy Products, Boosting Low Milk Prices

- The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is purchasing $148 million worth of dairy products, including $75 million in butter, $32.5 million in cheddar cheese, $20.5 million in fresh fluid milk, $10 million in Swiss cheese, and $10 million in shelf-stable Ultra-High Temperature milk.

- This purchase, authorized under the USDA's Section 32 program, is intended to stabilize farm products and provide food to federal nutrition assistance programs.

- The $148 million in purchases matches the amount requested by the National Milk Producers Federation (NMPF) in a letter sent to USDA last November.

- NMPF President & CEO Gregg Doud stated that these purchases will provide "important relief to producers" facing struggles in the agricultural economy, helping them provide dairy products to Americans and the world.

- Other recent USDA purchases to boost the farm economy include $80 million for specialty crops and $100 million for seafood.

- The USDA will invite offers from approved vendors and award purchase contracts following this announcement.

- NMPF represents over two-thirds of U.S. milk production and serves as the dairy industry's voice on Capitol Hill and with government agencies.

items.description: WASHINGTON (February 19, 2026) ‚Äì House Agriculture Committee Chairman G.T. Thompson released the text of Farm Bill 2.0 (the Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2026). The National Cattlemen’s Beef Association (NCBA) welcomes the...
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Farm Bill 2.0, also known as the Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2026, was released by House Agriculture Committee Chairman G.T. Thompson.

2. The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) welcomes the provisions in the bill that strengthen agriculture measures, including:

items.title: Bull management from the sale to the pasture
items.description: Bull sales are prevalent this time of year, and current sale averages are setting records. Taking care of that bull investment from the time of purchase until he is turned in on pasture for the...
items.summary:
Bull sales are prevalent this time of year, with current sale averages setting records. Proper management of the bull investment is critical during the transition period.

Bulls are often overfed during the weaning to yearling stage to maximize their growth potential. This can lead to them being overconditioned, with a body condition score (BCS) of 7 or higher on a 1-9 scale. Overconditioned bulls can have fertility issues and lack the stamina for the breeding season.

The recommended BCS for bulls at the start of breeding is 6-6.5. To transition overconditioned bulls, a 90-day period is ideal. This allows time for the bull to adjust to new feeds and surroundings, as well as complete a spermatogenesis cycle to resolve any semen quality problems.

When bringing in new bulls, a 2-4 week quarantine period is recommended for biosecurity. Gradual changes in diet are important, replacing concentrate with forage over several weeks. The target daily weight gain is 1.5-2 lbs, requiring access to high-quality forage (10% crude protein, 60-70% TDN).

Other management strategies include providing an exercise area with fresh water, and avoiding rapid, dramatic changes. Knowing the bull's previous feeding program can also help ease the transition.

The article emphasizes the importance of proper bull management from sale to pasture to protect the breeding season investment and ensure herd fertility.

items.title: Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There

Key points:

2) Farmers need to track field conditions, inputs, and yields to maintain compliance with regulations, certification programs, and contracts. This data can also improve decision-making.

items.title: Bayer proposes $7.25B Roundup settlement in cancer lawsuits
items.description: Bayer and attorneys for cancer patients announced a proposed $7.25 billion settlement to resolve thousands of U.S. lawsuits. The post Bayer proposes $7.25B Roundup settlement in cancer lawsuits appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Bayer has proposed a $7.25 billion settlement to resolve thousands of U.S. lawsuits claiming Roundup weedkiller caused cancer, primarily non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

- The proposed nationwide class settlement would establish a long-term claims program funded over 21 years, pending court approval.

- The settlement would cover claims from individuals alleging Roundup exposure before February 17, 2026 who are diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma within 16 years of the agreement.

- Compensation amounts would vary based on factors like age at diagnosis, severity of illness, and level of exposure - ranging from an average of $165,000 for agricultural workers under 60 with aggressive NHL to $10,000 for those diagnosed at 78+ with less aggressive forms.

- The settlement comes as the U.S. Supreme Court prepares to hear arguments in a case that could determine whether federal pesticide law preempts state failure-to-warn claims against Roundup.

- Bayer maintains Roundup is safe when used as directed, but is taking these actions to contain the ongoing litigation uncertainty.

- Approximately 200,000 Roundup-related claims have been made against Bayer, with mixed jury verdicts so far. Many other claims have been resolved through separate settlements.

- If too many plaintiffs opt out, Monsanto has reserved the right to terminate the settlement without making payments.

- Bayer has already removed glyphosate from Roundup products sold in the U.S. residential market and supports legislative efforts to limit litigation risk.

items.title: A Life in Rhythm: The Legacy of Armon Wolff
items.description: Some people are known for their sense of humor, others for their distinct style. Armon Wolff’s hallmark is his baritone voice and impeccable rhythm that resounded across auction blocks for over 60 years. Armon was...
items.summary:
He was born on the family ranch near Golden Valley, North Dakota in 1936. 

Armon's older brother Paul was an auctioneer, and invited Armon to help with his sales, but Armon insisted on first attending auctioneering school. In 1964, Armon's wife Peggy encouraged him to enroll at the Western College of Auctioneering in Billings, Montana, and the local banker was impressed by Armon's drive and gave him an extra $300 to make the trip.

After returning from school, Armon started selling household items and soon got the opportunity to sell livestock at the Missouri Slope Livestock Exchange in Bismarck, North Dakota. He eventually became the sole auctioneer at the exchange, selling multiple days per week at barns across the region.

Armon and his wife Peggy celebrated 70 years of marriage in 2025. They worked together running Wolff Auctioneers, the 2nd oldest auctioneering business in North Dakota. Armon won several awards over the years, including being Reserve Champion at the World Livestock Auctioneering Championship in 1979.

items.title: South Dakota governor vetoes bill banning lab-grown meat
items.description: South Dakota Gov. Larry Rhoden vetoed House Bill 1077 to block a permanent ban on cell-cultured meat, arguing it raises legal and free-market concerns. The post South Dakota governor vetoes bill banning lab-grown meat appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
South Dakota Governor Larry Rhoden has vetoed a bill that would have banned the sale of lab-grown (cell-cultured) meat in the state. The bill, House Bill 1077, passed the state legislature but Rhoden raised concerns about its constitutionality and potential to burden interstate commerce. 

Instead, Rhoden is proposing a 5-year moratorium on lab-grown meat to allow for further study and coordination with federal regulators. He argued that categorically banning federally approved products based on production methods rather than safety could lead to legal challenges and potential retaliation from other states.

The South Dakota Cattlemen's Association and other agricultural groups supported Rhoden's veto, stating that cell-cultured meat is not an unsafe product and that traditional beef producers can compete in the marketplace without a statutory ban.

As of late 2025, 7 states (Alabama, Florida, Indiana, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, and Texas) have enacted laws banning the sale, production, or distribution of cultivated meat, some of which are facing legal challenges. Cell-cultured meat is jointly regulated by the FDA and USDA at the federal level.

Consumer acceptance of lab-grown meat remains mixed, with concerns about "naturalness," processing, taste, and health continuing to shape public opinion. Investment in the sector has also slowed after peaking in 2021, with some high-profile companies scaling back expansion plans.
