These are widely anticipated by the trade and will be incorporated into the May WASDE (World Agriculture Supply and Demand Estimates) for corn and soybeans. The May WASDE includes the first official set of supply and demand tables for the new crop year. USDA expects a slight decline in total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybean to 224 million (down ~1%). This number assumes a normal level of preve
items.summary:
Total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybeans is expected to decline slightly to 224 million acres (down ~1%). 

Wheat acreage is forecast at 45 million acres, with a yield of 50.8 bushels per acre and total production of 1.86 billion bushels. The season-average farm price for wheat is projected at $5.00 per bushel.

Corn acreage is estimated at 94 million acres, with a yield of 183.0 bushels per acre and total production of 15.76 billion bushels. The season-average corn price is forecast at $4.20 per bushel. 

Soybean acreage is projected at 85 million acres, with a yield of 53.0 bushels per acre and total production of 4.45 billion bushels. The season-average soybean price is expected to be $10.30 per bushel.

These figures will be discussed on February 19 during the WILLAg.org Closing Market Report and Commodity Week programs. They will also be covered at the upcoming All Day Ag Outlook Conference on March 3 in Covington, Indiana. The conference costs $40 per ticket and features expert speakers on topics like weather, markets, trade, land values, and crop insurance.

items.title: COFCO delivers first cargo of certified soy to Vietnam feed sector
items.description: Responsible Agriculture Standard-certified soy shipment sold to feed ingredient provider for Vietnam‚Äôs poultry and aquaculture sectors.
items.summary:
COFCO, China's major food and agriculture conglomerate, delivered its first cargo of Responsible Agriculture Standard-certified soy to the Vietnam feed sector. The 25,000-metric ton shipment was sold to Harimex, a major Vietnamese feed ingredient provider serving the country's poultry and aquaculture industries.

The certified soy shipment was sourced from COFCO's operations in Brazil. It marks the first time COFCO has delivered certified sustainable soy to Vietnam, a significant market for animal feed. Vietnam's poultry and aquaculture sectors account for over 70% of the country's total animal feed demand.

COFCO aims to expand its supply of Responsible Agriculture Standard-certified soy to global customers as part of its sustainability commitments. The certification verifies that the soy was produced through environmentally and socially responsible practices.

This shipment supports Vietnamese feed producers' efforts to source sustainable ingredients. Harimex stated the certified soy will help them meet growing demand from customers for traceable, deforestation-free supply chains.

items.title: Nourishing your brain and body to reduce stress on the farm
items.description: Farm life doesn‚Äôt always lend itself to meal breaks. Yet a dietician recommends a consistent three-meal rhythm to see how nutrition supports mental wellness. The post Nourishing your brain and body to reduce stress on the farm appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Eating whole, nutrient-dense foods like whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins can help improve mental clarity, mood, and stress tolerance for farmers.

- Registered Dietitian Nutritionist Leslie Bonci recommends a consistent 3-meal routine, focusing on adding fiber, omega-3s, and hydration rather than restricting foods.

- Nebraska farmer Randy Uhrmacher found that packing healthier "tractor meals" made a big difference in his energy and well-being.

- New mom Andrea Veronica noticed improved long-term benefits from cutting back on energy drinks and instead relying on real food and supplements.

- Bonci stresses the importance of adequate hydration, aiming for 90 oz for women and 120 oz for men per day, and incorporating phytonutrients from fruits and vegetables.

- Making small, sustainable changes to eating habits can have a profound impact on reducing stress and improving physical and mental health for farmers.

items.title: Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years
items.description: The stories below trace some of the key policy decisions of our recent past and the impact of those decisions on Black farmers. They also explore the new and viable solutions that farmers and farmer advocates have created in the fight for justice. Below are our most important stories about Black farmers from the past […] The post Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
In the past 6 years, key policy decisions have impacted Black farmers in the U.S. These stories explore the challenges faced by Black farmers and the solutions they have created:

- The 1999 Pigford v. Glickman settlement awarded $1.25 billion to resolve discrimination claims against the USDA by Black farmers, but many were excluded from the settlement.

- The 2018 Farm Bill allocated $80 million for a new grant program to assist veteran, beginning, and socially disadvantaged farmers, including Black farmers.

- Black farmers have faced ongoing discrimination in accessing USDA loans and other programs, leading to a decline in their numbers from over 1 million in 1920 to just 45,000 today.

- Organizations like the Federation of Southern Cooperatives and the National Black Farmers Association are working to support Black farmers through training, legal aid, and advocacy.

- Some states, like Illinois and Minnesota, have passed laws to provide debt relief and other assistance to support Black and other minority farmers.

- Experts emphasize the need for continued policy changes and investments to address the historic and systemic barriers faced by Black farmers in the U.S.

items.title: Reading the Range in Winter: What Dormant Season Clues Reveal About Spring
items.description: Winter often feels like the quietest season on a ranch. Grasses are dormant, cattle are settled into winter feed sources, and it can feel like the landscape is resting. Yet for range and grazing management,...
items.summary:
Some key points:

- Dormant plants reveal the true impact of the previous year's grazing, without being masked by new growth or moisture recovery.

- Winter assessments offer 3 main benefits: clarity on residual forage/stubble height, predictive value for spring response, and lead time to make management adjustments.

- Important things to look for include:
  - Stubble height and residual forage - Uniform low stubble indicates overstocking, patchy low stubble suggests distribution issues.
  - Litter/ground cover - Sparse litter or bare ground patches signal chronic overuse or repeated grazing at the same time.
  - Grazing distribution - Snow and wind patterns reveal the previous season's livestock movement and grazing patterns.

- Proper dormant-season monitoring allows ranchers to "read the range" and make informed decisions about stocking rates, rest periods, and infrastructure improvements before the next grazing season begins.

The article does not provide any specific dates, deadlines, or expert quotes. It focuses on the general principles and rationale for conducting dormant-season range assessments to benefit spring grazing management.

items.title: Feedworks appoints first ruminant technical manager
items.description: Dr. Benjamin Wenner will focus on research, training, teaching and product innovation and will support U.S. sales of Calmin.
items.summary: Dr. Benjamin Wenner has been appointed as the first ruminant technical manager at Feedworks. In this role, Wenner will focus on research, training, teaching, and product innovation. He will also support the U.S. sales of Calmin, one of Feedworks' products. Calmin is a nutritional supplement for ruminant animals like cattle, sheep, and goats. Feedworks is a global animal nutrition company that provides solutions for ruminant, poultry, and aquaculture industries.

items.title: FFA says it will cooperate with congressional inquiry
items.description: The National FFA Organization says it will cooperate with a congressional inquiry reviewing one of its corporate sponsors. The post FFA says it will cooperate with congressional inquiry appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The National FFA Organization will cooperate with a congressional inquiry reviewing one of its corporate sponsors, Syngenta Group, a Chinese-owned company. The inquiry is being led by the House Ways and Means Committee and the Congressional FFA Caucus, who have raised concerns about foreign influence and whether the FFA is operating in line with its stated mission as a tax-exempt nonprofit.

The lawmakers, including Rep. Jason Smith, Rep. David Schweikert, and Rep. Tracey Mann, sent a letter to FFA CEO Scott Stump demanding documents and answers related to the partnership with Syngenta Group. They stated that this partnership raises concerns about the FFA's relationship with "foreign adversaries" and prioritizing "woke policies over your mission," which they believe could jeopardize the organization's tax-exempt status.

The FFA has reaffirmed its commitment to remaining nonpartisan and free from donor influence, stating that it "does not and cannot advocate the views for any donor or sponsor." However, the organization has declined to provide additional details, citing the ongoing nature of the investigation.

The inquiry comes amid heightened scrutiny from Congress over partnerships between U.S.-based nonprofits and companies with foreign ownership ties. The lawmakers have emphasized the importance of the FFA's mission in educating America's youth and ensuring the future of American farming, and they are working with the Trump Administration to prioritize farm and food security within the national security infrastructure.

items.title: Seek Labs awarded $2M for CRISPR bird flu therapeutic
items.description: USDA HPAI Grand Challenge grant will be used to develop a mutation-resistant therapeutic that remains effective as virus evolves.
items.summary:
Seek Labs was awarded a $2 million USDA HPAI Grand Challenge grant to develop a CRISPR-based therapeutic for highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), commonly known as bird flu. The goal is to create a mutation-resistant treatment that can remain effective as the virus evolves.

The funding will support Seek Labs' efforts to leverage CRISPR technology to target conserved regions of the HPAI virus genome, preventing the virus from mutating and evading the therapeutic. This is crucial as the virus has been rapidly evolving, with the current outbreak in the U.S. spanning over a year and impacting over 58 million birds across 47 states as of October 2022.

The USDA HPAI Grand Challenge was launched in September 2022 to spur the development of innovative solutions to combat the ongoing HPAI outbreak, which has caused significant economic losses for poultry farmers. Seek Labs was one of 12 recipients of the $2 million grants awarded under the program.

Seek Labs CEO Dr. Alina Alam stated that the company's CRISPR-based approach has the potential to provide a more robust and durable solution compared to current treatments, which have struggled to keep up with the virus's rapid mutation. The goal is to deliver a therapeutic that can protect poultry flocks and maintain food supply stability.

items.title: Light exposure in ovo may influence chick behavior
items.description: Chicks from eggs incubated in light instead of darkness interacted with their surroundings more.
items.summary:
Eggs incubated with light exposure resulted in chicks that were more active and interacted with their environment more compared to chicks from eggs incubated in darkness, according to a study published in the journal Applied Animal Behaviour Science.

The study found that light-exposed chicks spent 8.4% more time moving, 20.6% more time exploring their surroundings, and 16.6% less time sleeping compared to dark-incubated chicks. Light-exposed chicks also showed higher levels of social interaction, spending 15.1% more time in proximity to other chicks.

The study was conducted by researchers at the University of Arkansas and involved 120 broiler chicks split between light and dark incubation treatments. Chick behaviors were observed for the first 7 days after hatch.

The findings suggest that light exposure during embryonic development can influence important behavioral traits in chickens that may impact their ability to adapt to commercial production environments. Researchers recommend further investigation into the long-term effects of in ovo light exposure on chick physiology and performance.

items.title: Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 18, 2026 The post Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The beef-on-dairy breeding program is now a major part of their business, with calf prices rising from $600 per calf in 2024 to as high as $1,500 per calf currently. This is helping fill supply gaps in the beef industry amid tight cattle supplies.

Texas milk production increased from 17 billion pounds in 2024 to 18.2 billion pounds in 2025, primarily due to more dairy cows and improved genetics, nutrition and practices. However, milk prices declined from $20.55/cwt in Dec 2024 to $16.93/cwt in Dec 2025. Cheese prices also decreased from $18.62/cwt to $15.86/cwt, and butter prices fell from $2.50/lb in July 2025 to $1.50/lb by Dec 2025.

Texas dairy consolidation continues, with 20 dairies lost in the past 2 years (294 to 274), but cow numbers increased from 675,000 to 705,000 head. Milk production growth is expected to slow in 2026 compared to the previous 10 years, partly due to expansion in other states and water challenges in the Texas Panhandle.

The article also provides summaries of weather and crop conditions across various agricultural regions of Texas, including the need for moisture, winter wheat and pasture conditions, livestock feeding, and preparations for spring planting.

items.title: Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants
items.description: February 18, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced proposed rules Tuesday that would speed up line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. Under the proposals, maximum chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175. It would also allow turkey processing lines to increase from 55 […] The post Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has proposed new rules that would increase line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. The key details are:

- Chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175 bpm.
- Turkey processing lines could increase speeds from 55 bpm to an unspecified higher limit.
- Pork processing line speeds could also see increases, though the specific limits were not provided.

The proposed changes are intended to boost efficiency and productivity at meatpacking plants. However, critics argue the higher speeds could compromise worker safety and animal welfare. 

The new rules are currently in the proposal stage. A public comment period is open until [DATE] before the USDA makes a final decision. Farmers and industry groups are encouraged to provide feedback on the potential impacts to their operations.

items.title: Is beef x dairy needed in market data?
items.description: A Tennessee economist says the ‚Äúbeef-on-dairy‚Äù crossbreeding trend is reshaping the U.S. beef supply chain and should be tracked as its own market category. The post Is beef x dairy needed in market data? appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Main finding: The article discusses the growing trend of dairy cattle being bred specifically to generate calves that can be sold as beef. This "beef on dairy" segment of the beef supply chain has evolved from just a substitution during tight beef feeder cattle supply to a developed market.

Key statistics:
- In 2025, a 550-pound beef calf in Tennessee was valued at $1,851, compared to a dairy calf at $1,320 - a difference of $531.
- In 2025, approximately 25% of all cattle sold through U.S. markets were beef on dairy crosses.
- The U.S. cattle inventory is at a 75-year low of 86.2 million cattle and calves.

People/organizations:
- Charles Martinez, University of Tennessee agricultural economist
- U.S. Department of Agriculture's 102nd Annual Agricultural Outlook Forum

Context/causes:
- Dairy producers are using artificial insemination to make genetic-based decisions for dairy production while also intentionally using semen from beef bulls to produce calves for beef.
- Crossbred dairy calves command higher premiums compared to purebred dairy bull calves due to better carcass characteristics.

Impacts for farmers:
- Beef on dairy crosses generate strong revenue, providing a lucrative option for dairy producers.
- Accurately representing this market segment may be crucial for understanding the economic and operational implications for producers and the broader beef industry.

Recommendations/action items:
- Martinez proposes creating a new category for recording cattle market data: "beef on dairy" to better document this developing market.

items.title: Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors
items.description: Pellegrino joins the Department of Animal Science to study flavor, behavior and consumer decision-making The post Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Robert Pellegrino, Ph.D., has joined the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences Department of Animal Science as an assistant professor of sensory science. 

- Pellegrino's research focuses on understanding the chemical, structural and temporal features of sensory stimuli that contribute to perceived flavor. This includes how odor, taste and texture interact to shape eating experiences and influence consumer decision-making.

- Pellegrino has previously worked on digitizing odors, creating models to predict odor intensity and quality, and developing a universal odor scale. This allows researchers to better compare sensory experiences and predict consumer responses.

- Pellegrino will teach a course on sensory evaluation of foods starting in spring 2027. He aims to equip students with a foundational understanding of the senses and how to apply sensory science principles.

- Beyond Texas A&M, Pellegrino holds leadership roles with the Global Consortium for Chemosensory Research and the International Society of Neurogastronomy, focused on advancing sensory research globally.

- The department head, Clay Mathis, Ph.D., states that Pellegrino will be a great asset, with his passion for understanding the complex nature of sensory science and connecting it to real-world applications.

items.title: Life-Science Innovations to buy Hormel‚Äôs ‚Äòwhole-bird turkey‚Äô segment
items.description: Hormel Foods reached an agreement to sell several assets to Life-Science Innovations, including locations in Melrose and Swanville.
items.summary: Hormel Foods announced it has entered an agreement to sell its whole-bird turkey business to Life-Science Innovations (LSI). The sale is expected to close by the end of Q2 2026. Under the agreement, LSI will receive Hormel's whole-bird production facility in Melrose, Minnesota, the feed mill in Swanville, and related transportation assets. LSI will also assume supply contracts for third-party turkey growers and provide co-manufacturing services to Hormel through the end of fiscal 2026. Jennie-O branded products and the Jennie-O name will not be impacted. Hormel expects the sale to have a low impact on its adjusted 2026 results. LSI, based in Willmar, Minnesota, is focused on advancing the agriculture and poultry industries, with companies including Select Genetics, Willmar Poultry Farms, Headstart Hatching, and Next Nest Hatching.

items.title: Corn And Soybean Export Pace Outruns Last Year
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – Export demand continues to support grain markets as weekly inspections stayed large [...]
items.summary:
For the week ending February 12, 2026:

- Corn export inspections reached 58.8 million bushels, down from 63.4 million the prior week but still strong seasonally. Year-to-date corn shipments total 1.41 billion bushels, well ahead of last year's 974 million.

- Soybean export inspections totaled 44.2 million bushels, up from 42.1 million the previous week. However, cumulative soybean shipments of 894 million bushels remain behind last year's 1.32 billion pace.

- Wheat export inspections measured 13.8 million bushels, falling from 21.3 million the prior week but lifting the season total to 651 million bushels, ahead of 547 million last year.

- Sorghum loadings climbed to 9.5 million bushels, with year-to-date exports near 68 million bushels.

Shipments moved primarily through Gulf and Pacific Northwest ports, with China, Mexico, Japan, Egypt, and Southeast Asia remaining major buyers. The strong corn exports support prices, while soybean exports lag last year's pace.

items.title: Large Supplies Keep Grain Prices Under Pressure 2026
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Farmers preparing for spring planting face another year of tight margins as [...]
items.summary:
Corn acreage is projected at nearly 94 million acres, with production expected to exceed 15.8 billion bushels. Combined with over 2.15 billion bushels of beginning stocks, total supplies could top 18 billion bushels, keeping average prices near $4.33 per bushel.

Soybean acres are forecast to rebound to 85 million, lifting production near 4.46 billion bushels. However, ending stocks near 370 million bushels could hold prices around $10.31 per bushel, despite stronger exports.

Wheat acreage is expected to remain historically low, but large global inventories will keep supplies comfortable. Prices may improve modestly to about $5.46 per bushel.

Sorghum faces the heaviest pressure, as large beginning stocks outweigh lower production, leaving prices near $3.69 per bushel unless Chinese demand strengthens.

The main takeaway for farmers is that large carryover stocks will limit upside potential for grain prices, despite solid yield forecasts.

items.title: Dakota Skarlagen is the latest red potato released from NDSU
items.description: First red potato variety in a decade released from NDSU this month.
items.summary:
Dakota Skarlagen is the latest red potato variety released from North Dakota State University (NDSU) on February 15, 2026. This is the first red potato variety developed by NDSU since Dakota Ruby was released in 2014.

Dakota Skarlagen was selected in 2012, evaluated from 2013 through 2025, and has been replicated in research trials and by farmers since 2017. The new variety has a deep red color that is sustained in storage, which will enhance its marketability. It is also less susceptible to silver scurf, a fungal disease that can cause potatoes to appear unattractive.

The new potato variety has smaller tubers than varieties like Red LaSota, but more of them per plant, resulting in competitive yields. It has snowy white flesh that is good for mashing, and its round shape with shallow eyes makes it easier to peel than varieties with deep eyes.

Susie Thompson, NDSU associate professor and Johansen-Thompson Endowed Professor in potato breeding, believes the new variety is "wonderful" for both seed and commercial growers. Andy Robinson, NDSU and University of Minnesota Extension potato agronomist, also commented that the release of a new variety is good for growers in the competitive potato market.

During the Northland Potato Growers Research Reporting Conference, potato growers also heard updates on insect management, particularly the ongoing challenge of controlling the Colorado potato beetle, which has developed resistance to various insecticides.

items.title: FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics
items.description: February 17, 2026 ‚Äì Officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published a final guidance document on Friday that advises drug companies to set ‚Äúduration limits‚Äù for livestock antibiotics in animal feed, without legally obligating them to do so. The duration limit‚Äîthe maximum length of time a drug should be given‚Äîcovers medically important antibiotics, […] The post FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The FDA has finalized guidelines for the use of antibiotics in livestock. The key points are:

- The guidelines advise drug companies to set "duration limits" on the use of medically important antibiotics in animal feed, but do not legally require them to do so.
- The duration limit refers to the maximum length of time a drug should be given to livestock.
- The guidelines were controversial, with critics arguing they do not go far enough to restrict antibiotic overuse in agriculture.
- Overuse of antibiotics in livestock can contribute to the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which is a major public health concern.
- The guidelines were published on February 17, 2026 by the FDA.
- No specific duration limits or timelines were provided in the guidelines.
- Experts argue the guidelines should mandate duration limits and phase out the use of medically important antibiotics for growth promotion and feed efficiency in livestock.

items.title: Weaker Dollar Improves Export Prospects For U.S. Crops
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – A softer U.S. dollar is improving export competitiveness for American crops, offering [...]
items.summary:
Key Points:

- A softer U.S. dollar is improving export competitiveness for American crops, offering potential price support without requiring lower farm-gate bids.

- During 2025, the broad U.S. dollar index fell 7.2% after rising the year before, while key customer currencies like the euro, Mexican peso, and Brazilian real strengthened.

- A one-percent decline in the dollar has historically been associated with roughly a half-percent increase in the value of U.S. agricultural exports.

- The benefits do not appear instantly, as exchange-rate effects filter unevenly into basis and contracts depending on timing and location.

- For farmers, a weaker dollar supports export demand and may strengthen crop prices.

items.title: Proposed Rail Merger Could Reshape Grain Transportation Markets
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – A proposed $85 billion merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern could [...]
items.summary:
The proposed $85 billion merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern railways could significantly impact grain transportation markets if approved by federal regulators. 

The key points are:

- The merger would create the first coast-to-coast freight railroad in the U.S.
- Supporters claim it would streamline long-distance grain movements, especially from the Midwest to Southeastern feed and milling markets, by reducing interchange delays.
- The companies project $4.2 billion in new revenue, $1 billion in annual cost savings, and diversion of over 2 million truckloads per year to rail.
- Opponents warn the merged carrier could control over 40% of U.S. rail traffic, reducing competition and increasing freight rates.
- Opponents also cite risks of service disruptions, similar to issues during 1990s rail mergers that affected agricultural shipments.
- Regulators rejected the initial application as incomplete and require revised market-share projections and additional competitive safeguards before formal review continues.
- A revised merger application is expected in March 2023, with a final decision likely next year.
- For farmers, the merger could affect grain basis, freight rates, and service reliability across major producing regions.

items.title: How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question
items.description: Every dealer hears it:‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most reliable tractor you sell?‚Äù It sounds like a product question. It‚Äôs actually a trust question. Farmers aren‚Äôt asking you to crown a winner. They‚Äôre asking whether this decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most. Dealers who lead with a brand name risk missing the […] The post How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmers are not looking for a "winner" tractor brand, but rather want to know if the purchase will be reliable and avoid costly downtime.
- Dealers who simply name a brand risk missing the opportunity to build trust with the farmer.
- Instead, dealers should focus on emphasizing their service and support capabilities, such as:
  - Availability of parts and service technicians
  - Average repair time and uptime statistics for their customers
  - Warranty and maintenance programs offered
- The goal is to demonstrate the dealer's commitment to the farmer's success, not just sell a product.
- Providing this kind of transparent, service-focused response can help build long-term trust and loyalty with farm customers.

items.title: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care
items.description: Student-centered academic advising framework emphasizes mentorship and personalized support The post College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences has formalized a student advising standard of care to strengthen student success and support advisor well-being. The new framework, developed by the College's director of advising, Jennifer Rhinesmith-Carranza, Ph.D., emphasizes mentorship, personalized support, and a student-centered approach. 

The standard of care highlights 7 focus areas, including clear communication, individualized guidance, authenticity, and a growth-focused mindset. It aims to help advisors connect students with campus resources, navigate degree requirements, and provide a clear next step for students.

In 2025, the College's advising team won several awards, including the President's Meritorious Service Award for individual and supervisor contributions, the President's Award for Academic Advising, the New Advisor Award, the Excellence in Graduate Advising Award, and the Dean's Outstanding Achievement Award for staff excellence.

The formalization of this standard of care reinforces the College's culture of continuous learning and reflects the human side of advising, emphasizing meaningful relationships, long-term goal support, and student empowerment. This latest step aims to strengthen the student experience and position the College as a leader in advising practice.

items.title: As US agriculture flails, farmers see big corn acres as best bet to break even
items.description: Farmers expect corn, the most widely grown U.S. crop, to hew close to break-even levels this year, supported by strong usage.
items.summary:
U.S. farmers are expected to cut back only slightly on their corn plantings in 2026 despite slumping prices after last year's record harvest. 

Key points:
- Farmers expect corn to hew close to break-even levels this year, supported by strong usage, while soybeans are seen as riskier due to rising competition from Brazil and trade tensions with China.
- Analysts project corn plantings for 2026 at 94.9 million acres, down about 4% from last year's 89-year high, but still the second-most corn acres in 13 years. Soybean plantings are projected at 84.9 million acres, in line with the 10-year average.
- Last year's national corn yield was the highest on record at 186.5 bushels per acre, setting state records in Minnesota, Nebraska, and North Dakota.
- Farmers are looking to cut costs, with some in Nebraska stopping machinery purchases, reducing fertilizer use, and considering cutting back on herbicide applications.
- In North Dakota, farmers are delaying machinery repairs, skipping optional treatments on soybeans, and focusing input costs on corn as their most profitable crop in 2025.
- One farmer, Phil Volk, expects to expand his corn acreage this spring by 15% compared to last year.

items.title: Is sulfur a mobile nutrient? Carryover, soybean needs, and S fertilizer product differences
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Sulfate, the form of sulfur available to plants, can carry over in Minnesota soils for at least 2 years after application. Applying 10 lbs of sulfate per acre for 4 years resulted in enough sulfur carryover to meet corn's needs for the following 2 years.

- Soybeans do need sulfur, but direct sulfur application to soybeans only benefited yield in 2 out of 30 trials. Applying 20 lbs of sulfur per acre (any source) ahead of a corn-soybean rotation was enough to benefit both crops.

- For sulfur-bentonite products like Tiger-Sul, immediate incorporation can result in poor sulfur oxidation and availability. Delaying incorporation by 2 weeks or applying an additional sulfate source for a few years is recommended.

- Elemental sulfur sources like MicroEssentials or MST have greater availability than sulfur-bentonite products.

- The research was funded by AFREC and the Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council, and conducted by Daniel Kaiser, Extension nutrient management specialist at the University of Minnesota.

items.title: Minnesota potato council seeks independence in research and promotion work
items.description: A potato grower says the move to disassociate with the state's Department of Agriculture is a chance to deliver more funds towards potato research.
items.summary:
The council, which represents potato growers in all but northwest Minnesota's Red River Valley, has expressed its intent to terminate its current research and promotion council and transition to a privately funded and operated producer organization.

The key details are:

- The council was formed in 1991 to support and strengthen Minnesota's potato growers.
- The council collects a "checkoff fee" from producers to fund research and promotion for the potato industry.
- The council wants to terminate its MDA-administered status and become an independent, non-profit group.
- This would allow the council to save around $30,000 per year (over 10% of its budget) that was going to the MDA for administrative services.
- The council can make changes like increasing the checkoff rate more quickly as an independent organization, rather than going through the MDA's 12-month process.
- The council received unanimous support from its board and members for this transition.
- A public hearing will be held on February 25, where the council will consider final action on the termination.
- If approved, the termination will be effective on July 1.

This change will allow the Minnesota potato growers to have more autonomy and direct more of their checkoff dollars towards research work rather than administrative overhead costs.

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
In this episode of the Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interviewed Dr. Bob Stupar, a Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics and Legume Geneticist at the University of Minnesota.

Key points:
- Dr. Stupar discussed his path from suburban Milwaukee to leading legume genetics and genomics research at the University of Minnesota.
- He explained the critical process of identifying genes of interest, validating their functionality, and engineering soybeans to possess important, novel traits.
- Maintaining and updating reference genomes, the essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement, is crucial and can have a significant impact, as illustrated through historical examples.
- Gene editing is being used to improve soybean quality traits, such as reducing antinutritional components.
- Dr. Stupar's proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

The Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, discusses the progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops, featuring specialists from various crops and agronomic disciplines.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has relied on SNAP to support their family and their small business. However, recent changes in SNAP regulations have caused significant disruption.

Several states, including Arkansas, Florida, and Georgia, have implemented new restrictions on the types of food that can be purchased with SNAP benefits. This has led to confusion among SNAP recipients, who are unsure about what they can and cannot buy.

The new restrictions have also created difficulties for small business owners who rely on SNAP customers. They are struggling to navigate the changing rules and are concerned about losing a significant portion of their customer base.

Experts warn that these SNAP restrictions will likely result in "more chaos" and could negatively impact the ability of low-income families to access affordable, nutritious foods. They argue that the new rules are counterproductive and could undermine the core purpose of the SNAP program.

Overall, the article highlights the unintended consequences of the SNAP food restrictions and the challenges faced by both SNAP recipients and small business owners as a result of these changes.

items.title: The Power of Perennial Agriculture
items.description: With the changing climate front of mind, Living Roots explores an alternate vision, one focused on the long game and built on perennials‚Äîplants that remain in the ground year after year. Edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug, the collection of 34 essays by Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs makes a case for centering perennial […] The post The Power of Perennial Agriculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The book "Living Roots" edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug compiles 34 essays from Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs advocating for a shift towards perennial agriculture.

- Perennial agriculture focuses on crops that remain in the ground year-round, unlike annual crops that are replanted each season.

- This approach is seen as more sustainable and resilient in the face of climate change, as perennial plants have deeper root systems and require fewer inputs.

- Experts argue perennial agriculture can improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and provide more consistent yields over the long term compared to annual crops.

- Perennial crops highlighted include trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants that produce food, fiber, and other agricultural products.

- Implementing perennial agriculture requires changes to farming practices, infrastructure, and policies to support this transition away from annual monocultures.

- Indigenous communities in particular are highlighted as leaders in developing perennial agricultural systems that work in harmony with local ecosystems.

The article advocates for greater adoption of perennial agriculture as a climate-smart, sustainable alternative to conventional annual crop farming.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office
items.description: Facility to serve as emergency response training hub and staging area The post Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service is breaking ground on a new $2.1 million, 5,500-square-foot regional office in McGregor, Texas. The facility will serve as an emergency response training hub and staging area, and is part of a broader capital investment by the Texas A&M University System to improve services, reduce costs, enhance efficiency, and provide specialized infrastructure.

The new office is expected to be completed by the end of 2026 and will reach full operational capacity shortly thereafter. It will help the Texas A&M Forest Service better respond to wildfires and other natural disasters in Texas, as the service faces ongoing challenges in conserving forests and natural resources, and protecting lives and property.

The groundbreaking was attended by Texas A&M Forest Service leadership, Texas A&M University System officials, and local community leaders. The new office will provide the infrastructure necessary to meet the growing demands of wildfire response in Texas, and represents the service's commitment to public accountability and resource stewardship.

items.title: As carbon pipeline efforts stall, company eyes trucking the gas through North Dakota
items.description: Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is considering transporting CO2 from Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown for underground storage.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is exploring trucking carbon dioxide emissions from its Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown, North Dakota, about 160 miles west for underground storage.

2. The company requested a $20 million loan from North Dakota's Clean Sustainable Energy Authority (CSEA) in late January for its $95 million project, but the CSEA board voted against providing the funding.

3. Harvestone already operates a carbon storage facility at its Blue Flint ethanol plant near Underwood, North Dakota, where the CO2 has been pumped underground into the Broom Creek Formation since 2023.

4. Transporting CO2 by truck would not be a new practice, but the scale Harvestone is considering is. They plan to capture and store 230,000 metric tons of CO2 annually.

5. Building a pipeline to transport Dakota Spirit's emissions would be expensive, as a 160-mile pipeline would only move about 1,430 metric tons of CO2 per mile, compared to Summit's 2,500-mile pipeline which would move about 7,200 metric tons per mile.

6. Harvestone has an engineering, procurement and construction agreement with Minnesota-based McGough for the project, with a "guaranteed substantial complete" date in January 2027 and full commercial operations planned for later that year.

7. The potential for carbon storage in eastern North Dakota is limited due to the area's geology, so some form of transportation would be needed if companies want to capture, store or use industrial emissions from the region.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
The study conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025 evaluated how spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing affected waterhemp control in a corn herbicide program. 

The treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS, with or without a pH-lowering and buffering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot), and mixed either six days prior to application or at the time of spraying.

Adding the pH-lowering adjuvant reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8, which improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT. Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% in treatments with the pH adjuster.

The timing of mixing the pH adjuster (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density, or biomass. The improved weed control was observed at both full and half rates of Acuron GT.

The key takeaway is that conditioning the spray water to the proper pH can improve herbicide performance and season-long waterhemp management, regardless of when the solution is mixed. Testing water pH and using a water conditioner or buffering agent is recommended if waterhemp control has been inconsistent.

The study was conducted by Eric Yu and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educators, and was published on February 17, 2026 in the UMN Crop News.

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Requires soil temperature of at least 40¬∞F (4¬∞C).

Kale - A multipurpose cover crop that feeds the soil, farmer, customers, and livestock. Needs slightly warmer soil of at least 45¬∞F (7¬∞C). Certain varieties are specialty market items.

Daikon Radish - Also called forage radish, the long taproots reach deep into the soil to break up compaction and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil temperature of at least 65¬∞F (18¬∞C).

Oats - Grow quickly to prevent weed germination. Form beneficial relationships with fungi. Sow at a rate of 4-6 oz per 100 sq ft. Can be terminated without harvesting oats.

Buckwheat - A quick-maturing phosphorus scavenger that conditions poor soils. Attracts pollinators and beneficial insects. Can be used as an organic mulch.

The article notes that low tunnels can provide extra warmth and protection for cover crops in colder climates. Planting cover crops before spring can lead to economic benefits for farms through improved soil health, carbon sequestration, and erosion prevention.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
The webinar series runs through March and is still open for registration.

Key points:
- Cold weather impacts on overwintering insect pests like soybean aphid, corn rootworm, and alfalfa weevil. Colder temperatures (below 0¬∞F) can lead to 50-95% mortality for some pests.
- Forecasting tools like pheromone traps and degree day calculations can help predict arrival and development of migratory pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm.
- Crop disease forecasting tools like the ipmPIPE website track the spread of diseases like southern rust of corn and tar spot.
- The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides hyperlocal weather data and degree day models for various crops and pests.
- The North Dakota Ag Weather Network (NDAWN) hosts many of these forecasting tools, including models for sugarbeet root maggot, wheat midge, Cercospora leaf spot, white mold, and Fusarium head blight.
- Scouting fields is still important to validate the forecasting tools.

The article emphasizes how these advanced forecasting tools can help Minnesota farmers better time management practices and prepare for crop and pest threats.

items.title: Help the Crops Team fine-tune programming!
items.summary: The University of Minnesota Extension Crops team is seeking input from row crop and forage producers, as well as agriculture professionals who work with producers, to better understand their educational needs and preferences. They are conducting an anonymous 12-15 minute survey to gather this feedback, with the goal of customizing their educational programs to better meet the interests and preferences of the target audience. The survey asks about respondents' operations, learning preferences, and how they want to engage with Extension. The Crops Team aims to use the survey results to refine their programming and make it more useful and relevant for producers. The survey is open until February 16, 2026, and the team encourages all interested parties to participate.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging from -30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm 50s.
2. Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night, creating ideal conditions for frost seeding.
3. Frost seeding involves broadcasting or overseeding legumes into a thinning pasture or small grain stand, taking advantage of the freeze-thaw cycle to work the seed into the soil.
4. Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes, but success depends on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
5. For more information on best practices for frost seeding, readers are encouraged to review the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" article in the Encyclopedia.
6. The article was written by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University, who joined the Department of Agronomy in November 2023.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, like red clover, into a tired pasture or small grain stand to revitalize the stand in a cost-effective way.

- Timing is critical - frost seeding is typically done between mid-February to early March, coinciding with the freeze-thaw cycle, which helps incorporate the seed into the soil.

- Soil conditions are important - a thick thatch can hinder seed-to-soil contact, so it's recommended to closely hay or overgraze in the fall/winter prior to frost seeding. Sandy soils are less ideal as they don't expand/contract as much during freeze-thaw.

- Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding. The success of frost seeded stands depends significantly on spring moisture levels.

- The author is Dr. Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined Iowa State University in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: All Day Ag Outlook Conference March 3 at the Beef House
items.description: The 36th annual All Day Ag Outlook will be held Tuesday, March 3, at the Beef House in Covington, Indiana. Join the WILLAg analysts and the farmdoc team for the day. We’ll cover the basics this year, including the markets, weather, weeds, trade, competition, land values, and crop insurance decisions. Click the registration link for complete details. Doors open at 7:30 a.m. central / 8:30 a.m. eastern and include both coffee and rolls in the morning and a Beef House lunch.…
items.summary:
The 36th annual All Day Ag Outlook conference will be held on Tuesday, March 3, 2026, at the Beef House in Covington, Indiana. The event, organized by the University of Illinois Extension and the farmdoc team, will cover various agricultural topics, including markets, weather, weeds, trade, competition, land values, and crop insurance decisions.

The conference will feature presentations by experts such as Eric Snodgrass from Nutrien Ag Solutions on weather outlook, Joe Janzen from the University of Illinois on grain market fundamentals, and Joana Colussi from Purdue University on South American competition. Additionally, there will be panels on soybeans and corn featuring analysts from the WILLAg team.

Registration for the event is $40 per person if done by February 27, 2026, and $60 thereafter. Media members can register for free. The conference will start at 7:30 a.m. Central Time (8:30 a.m. Eastern Time) and includes coffee, rolls, and a Beef House lunch.

The conference will also cover topics such as weed management with Aaron Hager from the University of Illinois, the value of farmland with Bruce Sherrick from the University of Illinois, and where to trim crop budgets with Nick Paulson from the University of Illinois. Gary Schnitkey from the University of Illinois will also provide insights on crop insurance decisions.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This can be done in protected environments like greenhouses, cold frames, or even in the home. Key vegetables to start from seed in February include:

- Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary, which can take 1-4 weeks to germinate.
- Tomatoes, which need 80+ days from seed to fruit and do best with a heat mat. Opt for determinate varieties in short seasons.
- Peppers, which can take up to a month to sprout and need 2+ months to mature. Jalape√±o, serrano, and shishito are good productive options.
- Brassicas like broccoli, cabbage, and kale, which thrive in cool spring weather. Faster-maturing Asian brassicas work well in warm climates.
- Lettuces, which grow quickly and can handle some late frost. Both leaf and heading lettuces can be sown.
- Carrots and parsnips, which need to be direct sown in their final location due to sensitive taproots.
- Onions and leeks, which take 1-2 weeks to sprout and 75-140 days to mature.

The article recommends using protected growing environments like greenhouses, cold frames, and low/high tunnels to extend the growing season, especially in cold climates. Proper seed starting, potting up, and fertilizing are also key for success.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this past week were 8-18 degrees below average, with lows reaching -7¬∞F in Taylorville and -4¬∞F in Jerseyville. January as a whole was about 2 degrees below normal statewide. Precipitation was scarce, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches of light snow. January ended around 2 inches drier than normal statewide. While some areas like Du Quoin had over 20 inches of snow, it only yielded less than 1 inch of liquid water, providing little drought relief.  

Looking ahead, temperatures are expected to warm up to the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will remain sparse at under 0.1 inches. The third week of February is forecasted to be warmer and wetter than average as a more active weather pattern moves in. 

The article also features comments from experts on the importance of using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to maximize profits rather than just yields. These tools help farmers optimize nitrogen applications to protect local water quality while maintaining their bottom line.

The article mentions the weekly WILLAg.org radio programming, including the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report podcasts.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Farmers are now using AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without needing to click. The true indicator of content effectiveness is now the time a user spends meaningfully engaged, as this signals real interest and creates stronger opportunities for brand messaging.

AgWeb.com recently underwent a redesign to increase user attention and engagement:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in daily article pageviews per mobile user

The article notes that in general, only 16% of users read every word on a page, while 79% scan rather than read fully. Deeper scroll behavior and more articles consumed per visit indicate greater attention and focus.

Attention time is a better indicator than click-through rate, as it measures whether users stayed with the content, scrolled with purpose, and consumed multiple articles - behaviors that directly influence brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness.

The improvements on AgWeb provide a template for increasing engagement and attention, leading to higher quality impressions and better alignment with how farmers search and consume content today. This matters for ag marketers looking to reach farmers in focused, engaged moments.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
Key Findings:
- Field trials were conducted in 2024-2025 at 6 sites in central Illinois and north-central Iowa to evaluate soybean performance under different tillage (conventional, strip-till, no-till) and cover crop (no cover, cereal rye) systems.
- Starter fertilizer (15 lb N/ac or 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac) was evaluated in each system.
- Soybeans showed an early-season response to starter fertilizer, with increased biomass at V4 stage. However, this did not translate to higher yields.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across trials. Yields were similar across tillage/cover crop systems, with conventional tillage and strip-till averaging 78.4 bu/ac, no-till at 77.6 bu/ac, and no-till with cereal rye at 76.2 bu/ac. 
- While yields were comparable, differences in profitability emerged due to varying input costs. No-till had the highest partial net return, followed by strip-till and conventional tillage. No-till with cereal rye had the lowest partial net return due to cover crop management costs.
- The study will continue in 2026 to track longer-term impacts on soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics in conservation systems.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Greenhouses trap thermal heat to warm plants, with some featuring vents, irrigation systems, and climate controls. Different types of greenhouses include modular plastic, low tunnels, cold frames, and designer greenhouses with concrete foundations and climate controls. 

For February greenhouse growing, good options include:
- Tomatoes and peppers, which benefit from early planting to give their long germination time
- Brassicas like kale, cabbage, cauliflower, and broccoli to get an early harvest before spring pests arrive
- Lettuces, which can be grown as baby greens or full-sized heads
- Potatoes, to get full-sized tubers or baby potatoes by spring
- Onions, including sets, seeds, and bunching onions
- Flowers like lisianthus, coneflowers, and dahlias that take a long time to sprout

Proper greenhouse setup is key, with considerations around heat, ventilation, lighting, and pest protection. Greenhouses can raise temperatures by 2-30¬∞F compared to outside, depending on the design.

The article does not provide any specific dates, prices, or expert quotes. It focuses on the general principles and recommended crops for February greenhouse growing across different regions and greenhouse types.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference
items.description: Kansas City, MO., (January 28, 2026) ‚Äì  The Packer, the produce industry‚Äôs premier publication from Farm Journal, announced the launch of The Avocado Conference, a first-of-its-kind international event gathering every segment of the U.S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. The conference directly […] The post Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference appeared first on Farm Journal.

S. avocado supply chain, taking place on November 18-20, 2026 in San Diego, California. The inaugural conference aims to bring together every segment of the avocado industry - including producers, exporters, importers, packers, retailers, and foodservice buyers - to collaborate, share data-driven insights, and align on strategies to strengthen the avocado category.

Key details:
